TI: BEHAVIOR TOWARD VOCALIZATIONS OF THE SIBLING SPECIES INTERSPECIFIC TERRITORIALITY AND HABITAT IN THE GOLDCREST AND FIRECREST REGULUS-REGULUS REGULUS-IGNICAPILLUS
AU: BECKER P H
AB: Playback experiments showed that Goldcrest (Wg) and Firecrst (Sg) not only possess species specific songs, but also calls which are distinguished from those of the sibling species. The territories of the 2 spp. normally overlap in areas where they occur syntopically. In Central Europe 2 of 35 Sg-.male. were interspecifically territorial, while no interspecific territoriality was found among 35 Wg-.male.. The highest population densities of Wg and Sg in Central Europe are attained in spruce and fir forests. There is no evidence for the preference of deciduous forests by Sg, nor for the displacement of Sg into such forests by Wg. Pine forests are avoided by both species. Playback experiments support the results of sonagraphic analysis which showed neither character displacement in sympatric areas nor a reduced contrast in the songs of allopatric areas. Interspecific territoriality occurs only exceptionally. In 2 areas of Spain near Soria and Luarca a higher number of interspecifically territorial .male. (Soria: 6 of 17 Sg, Luarca: 2 of 4 Wg), as well as males singing both Wg and Sg songs (or mixed songs), were found in the species with a much lower population density. This can be explained through incorrect imprinting on the song of the sibling species and is not attributable to increased song similarity ecological factors or hybridization. Allopatrically occurring Wg-.male. do not react any more than sympatrically occuring Wg to the song of Sg, but 53 and 64% of Sg-.male. in 2 areas where only Sg occurs react to the song of the sibling species. Since reduced contrast in the song has been disproved as the reason for this, it may be that allopatrically occuring Sg possess a less selective releasing mechanism. This would mean that when in sympatry with Wg, Sg must learn not to react to the song of the sibling species. In Wg and Sg, reaction to the song of the sibling species, interspecific territoriality and mixed singing males seem to be the result of errors in the imprinting processes.

TI: BIRDS OBSERVED IN A SECTOR OF LAKE RINIHUE VALDIVIA PROVINCE CHILE WITH DATA ON THEIR ECOLOGY
AU: SCHLATTER R P
SO: Boletin de la Sociedad de Biologia de Concepcion
AB: A bird survey of an area of Lake Rinihue, Valdivia Province [Chile], yielded 58 spp. most of which (50%) were observed on regrowth of previously burned forest. Species (15) were recorded to breed. Most of the species were seen in one of 5 different habitats surveyed, only 1 spp. occurred in all of them. The presence of species in different habitats was analyzed. Five species revealed ample ecological plasticity in that respect. The scarcity of waterbirds on the lake as compared to others surveyed in the region, is stressed and the causes are analyzed. The food items of the flying steamer duck, based on fecal pellet analysis, revealed Aegla abtao (Crustacea, Decapoda, Anomura) and Chilina sp. (Gastropoda, Pulmonata). Based on general casting analysis from the Chilean burrowing owl, Aegla sp. was an important food item. The southern tinamou was not as vulnerable in the region as recently thought, nor is the torcaza (Chilean pigeon) endangered as in the past decade.

TI: BEHAVIOR AND ECOLOGY OF THE AMERICAN KESTREL FALCO-SPARVERIUS
AU: BALGOOYEN T G
SO: University of California Publications in Zoology
AB: In April, American kestrels (F. sparverius L.) return to habitats of burned forest and sagebrush-forest edge at Sagehen Creek, in the Sierra Nevada [USA]. Because of persistent snow and inclement wheather, kestrels hunt throughout most of the day in areas devoid of snow, cruising over large parcels of land in search of prey. Kestrel reoccupied some 61% of their territories from the previous year. Breeding activities of kestrels include copulation, territorialism, vocalizations, aerial displays, joint hunting, nest-site inspection and production feeding. Annual philopatry may also facilitate pairing. Copulation and defense of territory by males initiate the breeding season. Promiscuity occurs early in the season. As soon as the female associates with only 1 male, pairing is consummated. The female ceases to hunt and depends on the male for food. Coupled with this division of labor is a division of space; the female remains in 1-2 acres about the nest-tree while the male hunts farther away on the 109-ha territory. The caching of food by either sex assures food availability during the early to mid part of the breeding season. Because of its excavation of nest-cavities, the common flicker (Colaptes cafer) is a critical ecological element in kestrel biology. The kestrel out-competes other cavity-nesters except various squirrels. Kestrels prefer nest-trees on an east-facing slope or nest entrance pointing to the east. An eastern exposure provides protection from prevailing storms and facilitates warming of the nest in the morning. Kestrels select nest-trees located in sheltered basins. Protection from stormy weather, access to suitable hunting grounds, and easy transport of prey to the nest influence the choice of the nest-tree location. Kestrel females lay 4 eggs/clutch on the average, and produce successive eggs in a clutch at the rate of 1 egg each day. Females probably lay a determinate number of eggs but re-nest if the entire clutch is destroyed. Kestrels start a continuous incubation as the clutch nears completion. Both sexes incubate, but the male accounts for only 20% of the 29-31 days of incubation. Predation, chilled or infertile eggs, and wind damage to the nest-tree account for egg loss. Disease and parasites are not important mortality factors for kestrels. Young kestrels reach adult weight 16-19 days from hatching. Up to 7-10 days post-hatching, the male continues to supply all food for the family. As the food demand increases, the female resumes hunting. Parents feed the young throughout the day when prey is readily available. The young fledge after 29-31 days. A close sibling flock develops and persists until the young disperse. The success of fledging at Sagehen reaches 98.0% of young hatched, making the total reproductive output 87.5% of eggs laid. Parental defense insures a high survival of the fledglings. By late Sept., most kestrels have independently departed from the territory. Low temperatures and/or reduced amounts of daylight, and not food shortage, seem to be the proximate causes stimulating the southward movement of kestrels. Food availability is super-abundant on an average territory of 109.4 ha. An average family of 6 uses only 1.6% by weight of the food available. Male kestrels supply 49.6% of the needed food (15.540 g), and the female and young account for the remainder. The breeding system of kestrels allows for division of both labor and space. The male obtains food for the pair, and later for the young, in areas far from the nest-tree where the female confines her activities. This strategy conserves energy of the female which is expended in production. A smaller male needs less energy in the capture and transport of food, leaving more food for the dependent female. Kestrel hunting methods include still-hunting from perches (97.2%), hovering (1.8%), hawking flights (1.0%) and foraging on the ground (rare). Kestrels capture prey on or near the ground in short, open vegetation, regardless of habitat type. Kestrels take different types of prey more or less in proportion to their abundan.

TI: MEDICAL ASPECTS OF SOME ZOONOSES
AU: GEAR J H S
SO: Journal of the South African Veterinary Association
AB: Some southern African zoonoses are discussed. Yellow fever is transmitted among monkeys and/or man by Aedes africanus, A. simpsoni and A. aegypti. Rift Valley fever is carried by cattle and sheep and is transmitted by A. caballus and Culex theileri. Sindbis and West Nile infections occur in wild birds and are spread by C. univittatus. Rabies involves Canidae and Viverridae (particularly Cynictis penicillata). Most wild and domestic birds are a source of imported chlamydial psittacosis; parrots and finches caused 2 outbreaks. Sheep and cattle are a source of Q fever (Rickettsia burneti), and wild rodents (particularly Rhabdomys and Otomys) are a source of tick bite fever (Rickettsia conori var. pijperi); both are transmitted to man by ticks. Humans become infected with Leptospira canicola by direct contact with dogs. Glossina morsitans transmits Trypanosoma rhodesiense (Rhodesian sleeping sickness) and T. brucei (ngana) from cattle to man.

TI: QUAKING ASPEN SILVICS AND MANAGEMENT IN THE LAKE STATES USA
AU: BRINKMAN K A; ROE E I
SO: U S Department of Agriculture Agriculture Handbook
AB: Aspen forms the largest and most widely distributed forest type in the Lake States [USA] where it occupies about one-fourth of the commercial forest land. There are over 13 million acres of aspen forest in Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan. The dominant species, quaking aspen, may grow in essentially pure stands but varying numbers of other species usually are present. Common associates in the Lake States include paper birch, balsam fir, jack pine, spruces, northern red oak, elms, big tooth aspen, red pine, or white pine. Over its wide range, aspen occurs on a variety of soils and sites. Growth rate varies with soil fertility and moisture. Tree heights at age 50 range from 90 feet on deep fertile loams to 40 feet on dry sands, rock outcrops, water-logged mineral soils, or peat. About 11% of the aspen type occurs on poor sites (Site Index < 50), 58% on average sites (Site Index 50 to 69), and 31% on good to excellent sites (Site Index .gtoreq. 70). Most Lake States aspen stands are young. About 70% are less than 40 yr old and only 4% are distinctly overaged. Over half the stands are pole-sized; a third are seedlings or saplings. Only 6% of the type is owned by industry; the rest is nearly evenly divided between public and small private ownerships. Aspen is one of the simplest species to manage because it is easy to regenerate from root suckers, and its intolerance causes early natural thinning and pruning. Even without thinnings, aspen stands on average and better sites produce cordwood along with some larger products in a short rotation. The only direct investment usually needed is treatment of residual trees and brush at the time of harvest to stimulate production and rapid growth of aspen suckers. The recommended practice is to make either a complete clearcut or a commercial harvest followed by cutting or killing the remaining overstory. The brush that is often present on the better sites may be controlled using prescribed burns, but application of approved herbicides is more reliable. Mechanical treatments also are effective although costs will be higher. Favorable growing conditions must be provided for aspen sucker development. Volume growth rate and yields are related to both site quality and aspen stocking. Average aspen yields in unmanaged mixed stands often are only 10 to 15 cords per acre. Pure, well-stocked aspen stands on excellent sites yield 60 or more cords per acre, but poor sites may not produce enough volume to be worth harvesting. On the better sites, a single commercial thinning from below should be considered at age 30 to 35 yr, especially where large, high-quality trees will bring premium prices in the final harvest. Periodic defoliation of aspen stands by the forest tent caterpillar or other leaf feeders may reduce volume growth during infestations. Trees of any age can be attacked by the aspen borer, but infestation is most frequent in poorly stocked or thinned stands. Hypoxylon canker is the most serious disease, resulting in death or breakage of many trees; infection may be reduced by maintaining well-stocked stands. Because losses to decay fungi increase rapidly in overmature stands, aspen harvest should not be unduly delayed. To minimize losses to insects and diseases, aspen should be grown in well-stocked stands and harvested promptly at maturity. Recommended rotations for aspen stands range from about 30 yr on poor sites to 50 or 60 yr on good sites. Growing continuous crops of aspen also plays a key role in maintaining other natural resources. Aspen suckers are a staple food of moose and deer. The staminate flower buds of aspen trees are a necessary winter food for grouse and stands of all ages provide favorable habitat for grouse and other birds. Aspen bark and twigs are the primary food of beaver. The easily regenerated aspen provides soil cover that helps stabilize the water regime, and aspen forests have considerable esthetic and recreation value.

TI: Autoimmunity and leukemia
AU: DUTCHER, RAY M.
SO: WENNER GREN CENTER INT SYMP SER
CT: Proceedings of an International Wenner-Gren Symposium on comparative leukaemia research, 20-23 September, 1965, Stockholm, Swed. Pergamon Press London and New York
AB: Organs and cells responsible for the immunologi-cal capability of the organism are involved in autoimmunity and the lymphoproliferative diseases including leukemia. X-irradiation and contact with certain chemicals are known to be involved in the development of leukemia, the viral etiology of the murine and avian disease is also well established. Autoimmune mechanisms may play a major role in the pathogenesis of leukemia. Cells of the hematopoetic system might become infected in utero or shortly after birth with a leukemo-genic virus. These cells then may be stimulated by the thymus to multiply at a rapid rate. The virus enters the body and then the cell while the host is still immunologically tolerant. This is to explain the preservation of the virus during the time required for its interaction with the cell and the development of cellular transformation. The resultant immunologically competent transformed cells may be recognized by normal "immunocytes" which synthesize specific antibody against them or their altered antigens. Or that clones of normal immunocytes are selected for by the altered antigens of the transformed cells satisfying Burnet's clonal selection theory. It is the transformed immunologically competent cell which no longer is capable of recognizing the body as "self" and thus commences open hostilities against the host In any event, the stage is set for autoimmunity to occur. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: From auth

TI: Rickettsioses in the USSR [Engl. summ.]
AU: ZDRODOVSKIJ, P. F.
AB: Among the endemic rickettsioses found in the USSR, Q fever is the most widespread. The disease is particularly prevalent in the spring and summer and in regions where livestock are reared, though it usually appears in a subclinical form that can be diagnosed only by serological means. The causal agent, Coxiella burnetii, has been discovered in many species of domesticated and wild animals and birds and in various species of ticks and mites, and there is a large reservoir of natural infection in Eastern Siberia, Central Asia, Transcaucasia and the Southern Caucasus. Next in importance is Asian tick-borne typhus, which occurs[long dash]mainly in spring[long dash]in Siberia and the Central Asian Republics. The causative agent is Rickettsia sibirica and ticks of the family Ixodidae form the virus reservoir. Other endemic rickettsioses that have been observed in the USSR are: boutonneuse fever, which appears sporadically in the summer months on the Caucasian coasts of the Black and Caspian Seas and is transmitted by the dog-tick Rhipicephalus san-guineus; murine typhus, which has occurred in the same regions in the autumn and is spread by the rat-flea Xenopsylla cheopis; and another tick-borne disease[long dash]rickettsial pox[long dash]which has been endemic in the Southern Ukraine throughout the year, but with a peak incidence in May-July. During the Second World War and the immediate post-war period, epidemic outbreaks of classical (louse-borne) typhus were prevalent in the extensive territories temporarily occupied by the invading army. Some time after the epidemic episodes had ceased, there began to appear in these regions sporadic cases of a disease that was distinguishable from classical typhus clinically by its benign nature and epidemiological-ly by the absence of any known source of infection, by the fact that lice did not play a role in its transmission, and by its age distribution (it occurred most frequently in middle-aged and elderly people and rarely in children, who are so very susceptible to epidemic typhus). A special investigation, employing the most modern serological techniques, was undertaken by the Rickettsial Diseases Department of the Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology of the USSR Academy of Medical Sciences to determine the exact nature and origin of this sporadic, benign disease. The serological studies disclosed that the disease in question was a sporadic form of typhus, often presenting an atypical clinical picture that is readily confused with conditions such as chronic influenza and catarrh of the respiratory tract. It was concluded that these cases of sporadic typhus in the USSR were due to recrudescence of a previous latent infection and that the disease was therefore identical with Brill's disease and was a legacy of the epidemics of classical typhus that were rife during the Second World War. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors

TI: Experiments with immunizations of laboratory animals and hogs with formaldehyde and UV-inactivated Aujeszky virus
FT: Versuch zur Immunisierung von Laboratoriumstieren und Schweinen mittels Formaldehyd- und UV-Strahleninaktiviertem Aujezky-Virus
AU: ZUFFA, A.
AB: Laboratory animals and pigs were immunized with the formaldehyde and UV-inactivated Aujeszky virus. Repeated applications of the inactivated virus caused a build up of antibodies against tested infections in mice and rabbits. In chickens, the antibody build up occurred only after application of the live virus. The passage of the virus in the tissue cultures had no noticeable influence on the immunogenity of the inactivated virus. No appreciable difference was noticed between the immunogenity of several viruses. In pigs, two applications of the inactivated virus, in doses varying from 2-10 ml, created no antibody build up. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. Burnett

TI: The medical consequences of thermonuclear war. I. Human and ecologic effects in Massachusetts of an assumed thermonuclear attack on the United States
AU: ERVIN, FRANK R.; GLAZIER, JOHN B.; ARONOW, SAUL; NATHAN, DAVID; COLEMAN, ROBERT; AVERY, NICHOLAS; SHOHET, STEPHEN; LEEMAN, CAVIN
AB: This article examines the short-term human and ecologic consequences in Massachusetts, of the "limited" thermonuclear attack on the United States postulated by the Holifield Committee report of 1959. A 20-megaton ground burst on downtown Boston would seriously damage reinforced-concrete buildings to a distance of 10 miles, and demolish all other structures. Within a radius of 16 to 21 miles second-degree burns would be produced, and clothing, houses, foliage, gasoline and so forth would ignite, producing a fire storm. Human survival in this area would be practically impossible. An estimated 2,250,000 deaths would occur in metropolitan Boston from blast and heat alone. Beyond the area consumed by fire, many persons would be exposed to lethal doses of radiation from local fallout. Fallout shelters could reduce the cumulative dose of radioactivity to levels compatible with survival. For many, access to shelters would be made more difficult by blindness produced instantly by retinal burning. Many sheltered survivors would be subject to acute radiation sickness and to the long-term somatic and genetic effects of radiation. Acute whole-body irradiation produces a variety of clinical syndromes, largely dependent on the dose of radiation absorbed. The similarity of presenting symptoms in persons who have been lethally irradiated and those who have received much smaller doses would create major diagnostic problems in the postattack period. Sublethal irradiation would increase the morbidity and mortality from pre-existing disease and from blast injuries, burns and infections. Long-term effects of radiation due to fallout would include increased incidence of neoplasia, stillbirths, congenital malformations and cataracts. Serious ecologic problems would result from thermal destruction of forests and widespread lethal irradiation of mammals and birds, accompanied by relative sparing of bacteria, fungi, viruses and insects, all of which are highly resistant to radiation. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors
SC: Physics
MC: Radiation Biology

TI: Rickettsial infections and ticks
AU: BERTRAM, D. S.
AB: The history of rickettsial infections of man, domestic animals and ticks is briefly traced, including proposals in recent years to restrict Rickettsia to species of rickettsia pathogenic to man and to assign other organisms to the genera Cowdria, Ehrlichia and Wolbachia. An account is given of, mainly, human tick-borne rickettsioses due to R rickettsi and allied species, and Q-fever due to R burnetti, with brief comment on heart-water fever (Cowdria rumi-nantium) and tick-borne rickettsioses of domestic animals (Ehrlichia spp.), with special reference to mechanisms of transmission and reservoir hosts in wild life. Non-pathogenic, rickettsia-like microorganisms in ticks, as yet hardly studied, are noted with emphasis on recent work on Wolbachia persica Suitor and Weiss 1961 in the tick, Argas persicus. In discussion, the importance of the different host-ranges of different tick species as an index to possible maintenance hosts, or reservoirs, of rickettsial infections and diseases is stressed, with some special reference to Africa where most known rickettsial diseases of man and domestic animals occur. Attention is drawn to tick parasitization of birds as potentially important to the dispersal, and survival, of rickettsiae in nature. Suggestions are made regarding possible applications of histochemical methods and electron microscopy in the future study of pathogenic rickettsiae and non-pathogenic, so-called symbiotic rickettsia-like microorganisms in ticks. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author

TI: Epidemiological investigations on a "Q" fever focus in an agrotechnical and zootechnical farm [Russian, German and English summ.]
FT: Recherches epidemiologiques sur un foyer de fievre "Q" dans une ferme a caractere agro-zootechnique [Russian, German and English summ.]
AU: ZARNEA, G.; Et al.
SO: ARCH ROUMAINES PATHOL EXPTL ET MICROBIOL
AB: During the years 1956-1958 a study was carried out on a "Q" fever focus in an agrotechnical and zootechnical farm. The first epidemic outbreak comprised 22 cases of disease of a respiratory type. The "Q" fever diagnosis was confirmed by complement fixation tests (CFT) with a C. burnetii antigen which were carried out shortly after the outbreak, and by the isolation of the pathogenic agent from one of the patients. At the same time, 38.98% of sera from the persons living on the farm gave positive CFT as follows: zootechnical department 31.53%; department of mechanics and transport 28.26%; administration and managing department 21.74%; household department 13.04%; and agricultural department 5.43% (the percentage rates refer to the total number of persons included by the respective department). Periodical repetition of the serological investigations showed the percentage rate of positive CFT to stay at about the same level during the whole period of observation, with a marked tendency towards an increased number of low titers (1/8-1/16) and a corresponding disappearance of high ones. Of the serologically positive cases 50.40% exhibited signs of disease, while 49.60% were completely asymptomatic. Typical cases occurred more frequently in the zootechnical department. CFT with C. burnetii carried out in cattle revealed the existence of 56 serologically positive animals (18.48% of the entire stock.) The number of serologically positive animals decreased at the subsequent examinations practiced at 6 months intervals, pari passu with the decrease of the enzootic potential. The highest incidence rate of positive CFT in animals coincided with the epidemic "Q" fever episode in humans. Titer increases of the CFT were noticed in cows during gestation or immediately after calving. Positive CFT and comparatively high titers (1/128) were recorded in calves immediately after birth. Serological tests in the domestic animals (dogs, goats, fowls) belonging to the staff of the farm yielded negative results. Extension of the investigations to include the natural biotope surrounding the farm resulted in the demonstration of the infection in the hedgehog (Erinaceus europaeus L.), the magpie (Pica caudata), and the buzzard (Buteo buteo). In other wild animals belonging to 18 different species as well as 1300 ticks of the genera Dermacentor, Haemaphysalis, and Ixodes the results were negative. The most plausible routes of transmission appear to be the respiratory one as well as contact with the animals, their dejecta, the placenta, and the fetal fluids. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors

TI: Studies on the social behaviour of Quelea q. quelea (Linn.) in French West Africa
AU: CROOK, JOHN HURRELL
AB: The Quelea, a weaver bird, is highly gregarious and lives in dense flocks. In Senegal these birds live along river valleys in the dry season, but in the rains move north and breed in enormous colonies in the thorn bush country. In the dry season the flocks disperse in the early morning and feed, rest at mid-day and congregate at night into the roost. When there are rice fields in the vicinity, there is daily aggregation at the feeding place instead of daily dispersal. Flock movements differ as "drifting", "synchronised" and "escape", depending upon individual speeds of reaction to companions. There is neither a flock fragmentation prior to breeding, nor an increase in "individual distance" of males prior to the establishment of territories. Courtship begins at the nest when it is half built. After the male's display, the female comes to the nest and hops about with him. Copulation follows. After pair-bond formation, a special mutual wing-quivering behavior reduces further aggressive behavior between mates. At the nest the female becomes dominant over the male but not generally in the territory around it. The species is monogamous. Each male builds one nest and assists in incubation. Territory defense is described. The males work as do the females in bringing in food for the young. Around the 12th day the young leave the nest, for a time remaining nearby. Young and parents recognise each other but the young may solicit food from other adults, and parents prevent the approach of other adults or other young. With increased wandering the groups of birds mix so that young receive food from adults other than their parents. The change from juvenile flocking behavior to that of the adults occurs as the young leave the colony. During incubation, test egg-removal and nest mutilations beyond the cutting of small holes resulted in desertion. Reorientation of entrance to nest caused changes in routes to the nest and increased aggressive encounters between previously peaceful neighbors. Fragmented and promiscuous courtship occurred at the singed remains of nests, and some nesting material was brought. Burnt colonies are always deserted, but those burnt in the first few days of brooding may be restarted elsewhere. The "vocabulary" of the species is summarised in an appendix. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. N. Ludwig

TI: Use of a power line right-of-way by game after chemical brush control
AU: BRAMBLE, W. C; BYRNES, W. R.
AB: Sections of a right-of-way were treated in 1953-54. Broadcast, semi-basal, and basal spraying were tried in different ways and one section was cut. Broadcast spraying with Ammate resulted in 90% bare ground. Fireweed, which is of slight wildlife value, dominated this ground the 1st year but gradually dwindled in later years; sweetfern, a shrub of some browse value to deer, increased later. All broadcast sprays killed such low shrubs as blueberry. Basal sprays caused little disturbance of shrubs and herbs; plant cover remained on 75% of area. All sprayed areas are gradually reverting to bracken-sedge-herb-blueberry type. No soil erosion occurred, for litter was not disturbed. Wildlife usage was studied by transect counts of scats and observation of sign. Results are tabulated. All areas were used by game animals. Deer apparently preferred unsprayed and winter basal areas. Rabbits may have preferred unsprayed, winter basal, and hormone-broadcast areas. The few turkey signs suggested preference for areas broadcast with hormone mixture or Ammate. Deer use of all areas increased over the 5-year period, but was less where brush was reduced. In spring and early summer, however, deer fed heavily on young shoots of herbs. Young turkeys used the grass-herb cover of broadcast areas for catching insects. Squirrels apparently "planted" acorns in the right-of-way[long dash]a practice that will complicate maintenance. Rabbits actually increased in treated areas, owing to more low food and cover and more woodchuck holes. In general, treatments benefited wildlife by creating more interspersion and edge. Broadcast spraying benefits some game animals and its results can be maintained by selective basal spraying. Initial basal spraying creates a tight cover that is relatively cheap to maintain and is highly satisfactory both to the utility company and to wildlife. Table lists major plants of right-of-way as of high or low seasonal value to deer, grouse, turkey, and rabbit. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy Wildlife Rev. 93.36. 1959

TI: A field study of the timber wolf (Canis Lupus) on the Superior National Forest, Minnesota
AU: STENLUND, MILTON H.
AB: Field data gathered during the winter of 1946-47 winters of 1948 through 1953. Pollen studies indicate conifers and jack pine, especially, were dominant vegetative cover since last glacial period. Extensive logging operations, 1885-1920, caused major disruption of natural plant succession. Major Umber wolf range in Minn. covers approximately 12,000 sq. miles. Wolf population is largest remaining in U. S. Although wolves and deer are found throughout Border Study Area, populations of both are higher in cutover area north of Ely than in uncut areas for at least 25 years. Cutover and burned over area supports more deer, and consequently more wolves. It is estimated that Forest supports a population of 240 wolves on an area of 4100 sq. miles or 1 wolf per 17 sq. miles. Wolf numbers reached a high during 1925-1940 and have since declined to a level above and below which they fluctuate. Records of 8 wolf litters were received, largest 9, smallest 4. 67 stomachs taken from winter-killed wolves were examined; 16 were empty. Deer (Odocoilcus virginianus) comprised 95.5% of total contents by volume and 80.4% by occurrence. Hare (Lepus americanus), porcupine (Erethizon dorsatum), and ruffed grouse (Bonasa umbellus) together made up 4.5% of total by volume. Among 156 wolves the largest male weighed 112 lb. and measured 69 inches; the largest female weighed 80 lb. and measured 61.25 inches. Male pups weigh 50 lb. or more by Nov.; female pups weigh 40 lb. or more. Of 156 wolves examined, 64% were males. Of 112 observations made from air and on ground, a total of 318 wolves was seen. Single wolves (48) made up 41% of all observations; largest pack was one of 15. A total take of wolves by man approximates 1 wolf per 41 sq. miles, or 41% of the population in major wolf range. Original white-tailed deer population was low. Build-up to a peak period reached in 1930's was due to (1) transformation of a virgin coniferous forest relatively devoid of extensive good deer habitat into a 2d growth hardwoods forest; (2) presence of thousands of acres of unbrowsed cedar swamps; (3) several restrictions placed on deer hunting. Decline in deer numbers was not due to overhunting or wolf predation but due to starvation from general range deterioration. This range deterioration due to almost complete elimination of cedar as an available food;.(2) overbrows-ing of hardwoods; (3) 2d growth timber reached maturity; and (4) natural succession toward a coniferous forest. There is no apparent food preference by wolves for either sex of deer. Wolves kill annually 1.5 deer per sq. mile from an estimated deer population of 9 per sq. mile. Hunters remove less than 1 deer per square mile in parts of Forest. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author
C1: Minnesota Dep. Conservation, St. Paul
SC: Environmental Sciences & Ecology

TI: Zoonoses in Australia. A conspectus of some clinical and preventive aspects
AU: SOUTHWOOD, A. R.
AB: Diseases transmitted from animals to man were not frequently noted in Australia but recent studies suggested that some ill-defined febrile illnesses may be found to come within the category. Murray Valley encephalitis, investigated by Burnet, Miles, Anderson and others, was shown to be closely related to Japanese B. encephalitis - arthropod-borne from wild birds in some spp. of which the infection was enzootic. Psittocosis-ornithosis, common infections of Australian birds, was occasionally transmitted to man; antibiotic measures had greatly lowered the case-fatality rate. Q fever, due to infection by Rickettsia (Coxiella) burneti, was first observed in abattoir workers by Derrick; the occupational hazard was apparently not the only source of spread, for many instances occurred of illness in people not so associated. Leptospiral infections, actively studied in the Queensland Institute of Medical Research by Mackerras and his colleagues caused febrile illness, sometimes with jaundice, in cane-field workers; other types of Leptospira were discovered, and at least 10 types are known; animal reservoirs include cattle, pigs, dogs, rats, and some Australian fauna. Hydatid disease, from the development of the cyst stage of Echinococcus granulosus, occurred mainly in people associated with dogs fed on infested uncooked sheep offal; methods of health education were being used to get the cooperation of farmers and others in applying the simple preventive measures. The National Health and Medical Research Council (Australian) was providing grants for continued studies in zoonoses. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: A. R. Southwood

TI: Preliminary investigation of the barren ground caribou I. and II
AU: BANFIELD, A. W. F.
AB: Rangifer arcticus arcticus is physically adapted to an Arctic environment: the hoofs are broad and large enabling support of body weight on crusted snow, and a cavity on the sole of the foot makes for sure-footedness on ice. Pelage and protruding parts are so formed as to meet best the cold conditions. Fat storage is in several areas; the most important that deposited over the saddle and rump. Fat accumulation in cows occurs later in the season than it does in bulls. Actions of insect pests often interferes with fat deposition. Among food requirements of caribou, certain mushrooms, lichens, grasses, and willows -seemed to be preferred. Discarded antlers are avidly chewed in winter months. Caribous are gregarious animals, usually found in small bands or loose herds. They are nomadic and there seems to be little sense of territoriality. They are almost continually in migration with seemingly no one factor being responsible for this movement. The character of the environment is changed when they move from an area, for a large number of such animals as wolves, ravens, eagles, and gulls are dependent on the caribou for food, and so form a mobile community. A small sample of caribou under one month of age gave a sex ratio of 175 males to 100 females, but at maturity the ratio was 35.8 males to 100 females, indicating a greater mortality among males. Cows are sexually mature as early as 17 months, bulls do not reach maturity until at least 2 or 3 years of age. Annual calf increment is about 21.6% of the herd, or approximately 145,000 calves yearly. Approximate annual loss to the herd is 178,000, resulting in a deficit of about 32,000 animals per year. Next to man, the wolf is the most important predator, but the annual loss to them is probably less than 5%. Wolverines, grizzly bears, and golden eagles are possible predators, but losses to them are considered as insignificant. Other causes of mortality were external and internal parasites, bacterial diseases and accidents. Of these, accidents, which cause the death of many caribou annually, seem to be the most important as far as primary causes of herd loss. The presence of Echinococcus granulosis is important, because it is a parasite of man. A foreseeable danger to the herd is the possible hybridization with the introduced domestic reindeer (R. a. asiaticus). leading to a general debility of the herd with the possibility of extermination of the native race. Fortunately, such hybridization seems unlikely at present. Man exerts his heaviest influence as a direct predator, but other activities including range distraction through forest fires are very important. Destruction of winter range through fire may be of semi-permanent nature, because of the slow growth in the sub-Arctic region. The caribou in this region is a basic factor in the economy of approximately 20,000 Canadians providing them with food, shelter, and clothing. A drastic reduction of 62% of the herd since 1900 has caused great concern. With increased demand for caribou products brought about by the opening of the area for trade, an increase in human population in this area, and the introduction of efficient firearms, the present population of caribou is large enough only if the kill is confined to basic needs and wastage is reduced. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: P. TI: Studies on the life-history of Symphoricarpos occidentalis Hook. in Minnesota
AU: PELTON, J. F.
AB: .S. occidentalis. or wolfberry, is a characteristic and common clump-forming shrub in the Great Plains and adjacent regions of the northern U. S. and Canada. It is valuable for wildlife, honey, erosion control, and livestock browse through much of its range, but tends to be a serious pasture weed in the eastern and northern areas. The sp. is particularly characteristic of the forest-prairie ecotone, where it functions in furthering the advance of the forest by invading the grassland by means of rhizomes. The shrub occurs naturally only in climates of a strongly continental type, and generally in well-lighted habitats. It tolerates a wide variety of soils, but does not occur on very acid, saline, organic, or permanently saturated substrates. The fleshy fruits are probably dispersed mostly by birds and mammals, in the digestive tracts of which at least some seeds seem to survive. The seeds have a double dormancy, requiring in nature the breakdown of their coats by fungal action in warm moist soil, followed by after-ripening and development during at least one winter in the soil. Germination takes place readily only between 5[degree] and 15[degree]C, occurring only in very early spring in nature. Drought, invertebrates, and damping-off fungi destroyed most of the first year seedlings in 1950 The mature stems vary in height, density, and diam. in response to age, position in the colony, and habitat. Shoot buds do not appear to have a long cold requirement. The roots are extensive, abundantly branched, and appear mycorrhizal. Mature plants are resistant to many extremes. Fire kills the stems but resprouting is abundant. Rhizome reproduction is very active, a much greater length of rhizomes often being produced than aggregate length of aerial stems. The sp. responds to long photoperiods, and flowers during much of the summer. The flowers are pollinated by a wide variety of insect types. Mechanisms preventing self-pollination are absent, but partial self-incompatibility appears to be present. Fruit production is heavy, but about half the seeds are defective. The main destruction of fruits appears to be by mice and livestock. Longevity of plants was observed to vary up to 13 years for stems and 40 years for rhizomes. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. Pelton

TI: Oak wilt panel discussion
AU: RIKER, A. J.
SO: NATL SHADE TREE CONF PROC ANN MEET
AB: The cooperative research projects organized in the U. S. to investigate oak wilt are described. The disease has been found in 18 states. It is known to spread by root grafts but the means of long distance spread are not understood. Unless the fungus is introduced into the vascular system of the plant, infection will not occur. As soon as infection occurs it spreads rapidly throughout the vascular system. The tree is known to produce spore mats for 3 to 9 months after death. Squirrels, woodpeckers, and insects, for example fruit flies, may serve to disseminate the fungus. Diseased oaks should be cut and burned as soon as discovered and if feasible the area between them and nearby oaks should be trenched to sever root connections. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Karl Dressel

TI: Opsonins for rickettsiae
AU: VICTOR, JOSEPH; RAYMOND, RUTH; VALLIANT, JEANNE; WAGNER, JOHN C.; POLLACK, ABOU D.
AB: An abstract. A method has been developed for the quantitative detn. of blood opsonins for Coxiella burnetii. An opsonin unit for C. burnetii :1s the quantity of opsonin causing phagocytosis of rickettsiae by 94-100% of polymorphonuclear neutrophiles under standard conditions. The opsonin titer is the number of opsonin units in 0.1 ml. serum or plasma. An opsonin titer of 1 occurred in 1% of individuals having no known contact with C. burnetii; in 30% of individuals previously vaccinated with chick embryo grown C. burnetii and in 31% of normal individuals where Q fever is endemic. Statistically, about 42% of people in the latter 2 groups showed increased opsonin for C. burnetii. Where Q fever is endemic, positive complement-fixing antibodies occurred only in 1/7 of individuals with elevated opsonins. In contrast, vaccinated individuals showed no relation between complement fixation and opsonin titers. Injn. of normal chick embryo yolk sac increased opsonins for rickettsiae grown in yolk sac. This may explain the different serological reactions of artifically and naturally immunized populations. In patients with Q fever, opsonin titers increased many million fold, often 10,000 times more than complement-fixation titers. This opsonin test may be used as an epidemiological and diagnostic method for detecting infection with C. burnetii.

TI: The action of T. foetus on the chick embryo
FT: Etude de l'action de Trichomonas foetus sur les embryons de Poulet
AU: Florent, A.
AB: Earlier workers have not agreed on the lytic action of T. foetus on the chick embryo but no lytic action could be demonstrated by any of the following procedures. Inoculations of the chick egg were made on the 7th day of incubation, using the technique of Burnet. The death of the embryo was detd. by daily candling of the eggs. Viability of the parasites was indicated by functional flagella. Although the eggs were not opened (except in one instance) for 1-6 days after the death of the embryo (in 8-20 days), there was no evidence of lysis. Parasites were recovered from the blood, the cavities, and the tissues of the chick. Eggs were placed in a refrigerator for 4 days after 5 days of incubation. The death of the embryo did not interfere with the increase in numbers of the parasite. Active T. foetus were found 13, 15, and 22 days after the embryo's death. Lysis occurred in 2 instances of accidental bacterial contamination. Three trials of 8 days each were made using a 5-day-old embryo which had been removed from the egg to avoid the dilution and probably consequent reduction in activity of the parasite's secretion by the surrounding embryonic fluids. Although Trichomonas flourished under these conditions, there was no evidence of lysis. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. B. Cross

TI: Brooder-stove residue burns on turkey poults
AU: Dickinson, E. M.; Clark, W. C.
AB: A condition occurring in turkey poults is reported in which the poults develop a dermatitis on the head and back due to exposure to tar-like residue which accumulates around some brooder stoves that are heated with gas briquets. If the poults are exposed to sunlight, the condition is greatly aggravated and the dermatitis appears as a 3d-degree burn. Exposure to sunlight causes itching and the birds scratch the areas severely. The condition was easily reproduced experimentally. In the treatment, it is important to prevent exposure to sunlight. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: M. S. Hofstad

TI: The effect on the chick embryo of the simultaneous inoculation of stool, streptomycin, and penicillin
AU: Hodges, John H.
AB: Thirteen-or 14-day old chick embryos were given 0.25-0.30 ml. of inoculum by the intra-amniotie method of Burnet. The eggs were sealed and incubated at 37 [degree]C. for 40 hrs. Three different stool specimens were obtained: 2 which were on dry ice for 1-3 mos., taken from patients with epidemic diarrhea and vomiting, and 1 fresh "normal" specimen. Controls contained sterile saline instead of stool suspension. After about 40 hrs. each egg was opened aseptically, the embryo observed, and fluid cultured. Death of embryos occurred in nearly all eggs which received stool suspension with saline or with petiicillin. Cultures from these eggs were always positive. In corresponding controls, about 2/3 of the embryos survived, and only 3 of 40 had positive cultures. Half the embryos survived in eggs inoculated with stool suspension, streptomycin, and penicillin. The same was true in corresponding controls. About 1/3 of the embryos survived when inoculated with stool suspension and streptomycin. The number of positive, cultures was about the same as the contamination rate in the controls. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: H. M. Kaplan

TI: The prairie chicken in Missouri
AU: Schwartz, Charles W
AB: The prairie chicken (Tympanuchus americanus cupido) in Missouri now occupies only 1/10 its original range, and its present population in the state is ca. 13,000, while the primitive population was tremendous. The reduction was caused by a destruction of its habitat by the agricultural practices of the late 19th century. The present occupied range is the few areas of prairie which were never plowed, and those which have recently been returned to grassland. The text of this richly illustrated book consists chiefly of brief explanations of the 84 full-page photographs from life, which portray graphically the life-history, habits, and ecological requirements of the prairie chicken in Missouri. A particularly valuable contribution is the detailed description of the "booming" and courtship performance in the fall, which is more complete than heretofore described. Management recommendations for increasing the population include the following: annual censuses based on booming ground counts, continued legal protection, establishment of permanent ponds, avoiding the cultivation of soils suited only to grassland, avoiding overgrazing, avoiding uncontrolled burning, leaving some portion of hayfields unmoved. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. Swanson

TI: The wild turkey in Virginia: Its status, life history and management
AU: Mosby, Henry S.; Handley, Charles 0.
SO: Col. frontispiece, 10 maps, 1 col. pl., 51 fig. Pittman-Robertson Projects
AB: The distribution of all 6 recognized subspp. of wild turkeys is mapped, but only the eastern form (Meleagris gallopavo silvestris) is considered in detail. While present turkey populations are only a small fraction of those in pre-colonial times the 4 subspp. found in the U. S. have apparently held their own in recent yrs., and increased in a few localities. In Virginia the 1938 wild turkey population was estimated at 22,575 birds in 2,020 flocks, distributed in 69 of the 99 counties. The present range in Virginia is 13,700 sq. miles, and an additional 2,200 sq. miles is potential range which should be developed. The annual kill 1927-1940 has averaged 6,808 birds as estimated by county game wardens. Regulations in 1941 allow hunting for 2 months except when a tracking snow covers the ground, but hunting pressure is increasing so more stringent laws are needed. Methods of hunting are described. The factors which caused the decline in turkey population and complete exterpation from many areas are: destruction of forests by lumbering, fire and agriculture; depredations by man and dogs; severe weather at critical periods; destruction of mast trees and other food plants by man and disease (chestnut blight); and possibly, diseases contracted from domestic poultry. The depredations by, man included trapping, in part for the market, until after 1900. The wt. of turkeys seldom exceeds 20 pounds, but a 30-lb. gobbler is reported, and a wild turkey raised in captivity reached 47 lbs. Hens averaged 8.32 lbs., gobblers 13.36 lbs. The turkey is polygamous, [male][male] attracting the [female][female] by gobbling. [male][male] seldom if ever mate until the 2d yr., but [female][female] mate the 1st yr. Of 27 nests of native wild turkeys studied, 67% were failures chiefly due to desertion. Man causes more destruction of wild turkeys than any other enemy. About 30% of the fall population is taken in hunting, 3% is wounded and lost, 10% illegally poached. Man is responsible for some of the nesting losses also. Predation by dogs, 5 wild mammals, and the great horned owl has been observed in Virginia; the owl is considered worst. The diseases and parasites of wild turkeys, including captive-reared, are: pullorum, coccidiosis, Leucocytozoon, blackhead, paratyphoid, tapeworms, roundworms, lice, mites, and hippoboscid flies. Studies based on 537 crops and gizzards, 495 of them taken in Nov. and Dec., revealed only the following foods in quantities over 1% (descending order of importance): Quercus, Cornus, Vitis, Zea mays, Smilax, Orthoptera, Rhus toxicodendron, Nyssa, Diptera, Fagus, Fraxinus, Rhus sp. Plant foods comprised 95% of the total. Turkeys prefer to escape by running rather than flying, but flights of a mile are recorded. Running speed is 12-18 m.p.h.; flight speed was measured from 32-43 m.p.h. Turkeys are propagated artificially under the "game farm method" and by use of large pens located in occupied turkey range where wild gobblers may enter to mate with the captive hens. Progeny from the "game farm" turkeys are of almost no value, those from "wild mated" stock are of some value, in restocking. The more important habitat requirements of the wild turkey are: an area 15,000 acres or more which is 50-90% forested with at least 25% of the trees mast-bearing hardwoods; free water well distributed; areas of 1000 acres or more which are refuge or otherwise undistributed; and suitable roosting sites, preferably in conifers. Chufa (Cyperus esculentus) was found to be one of the most promising of all plants used in turkey food plantings. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Gustav Swanson

TI: Nesting of the Hungarian partridge and ring-necked pheasant in Whitman County, Washington
AU: Knott, N. P.; Ball, C.C.; Yocom, C. F.
AB: During 1940-41-42, the success of 113 partridge and 147 pheasant nests was found to be more dependent on the amt. of permanent cover in proper relation to winter habitat than on weather or predation. Permanent cover comprises 12-32% of the land area; > 30% of the nests of both spp. were in such cover. The remainder of the land is used for the production of cereals and hay. Mowing, plowing of stubble and burning were the major factors causing the loss of 48% of the first pheasant nests and 63% of the Hungarian partridge nests. Re-nesting is often attempted if the first nest is destroyed. Broods from such nests contained fewer birds than those from original nests. The peak of pheasant hatching occurs during the 1st week in June, and losses from haying are less than in partridges which hatch about a week later. Exptl. studies have shown corrective habitat work to be possible and a program is being carried out by the State Dept. of Game. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: N. P. Knott

TI: Decay of western hemlock in western Oregon and Washington
AU: Englerth, G. H.
AB: Western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) is said to be one of the most important forest trees in the Pacific Northwest, where it attains its maximum development. In cruising and marking for cutting, forest officers often encounter decays which are not typical of the brown stringy rot due to Echinodontium tinctorium, which has generally been considered ubiquitous on this species. Because of this observation the present study was initiated and carried out (1935-40), involving the dissection and analysis of 801 trees for decay. Fomes annosus root rot was found responsible for 21 percent of the board-foot volume decayed, F. pini conk rot for 19.2, F. ap planatus white mottled rot for 17.1, F. hartigii white trunk rot for 10.1, Ganoderma oregonense white spongy rot for 7.2, F. pinicola brown crumbly rot for 6.7, E. tinctorium brown stringy rot for 5.3, P. oria colorea spongy butt rot for 4.3, Armillaria mellea shoestring-fungus rot for 3.7, Polyporus sulphureus brown cubical rot for 2.3. F. officinalis brown trunk rot for 1.5 P. schweinitzii red-brown butt rot for 0.9, and Polystictus abietinus pitted sap rot, F. subroseus yellow-brown top rot, and Poria subacida feather rot each for 0.1%. The various infection courts for decay in this tree were knots, falling-tree scars, roots, mistletoe burls and knots, broken tops, fire scars, lightning scars, and frost cracks. Though more infections occurred through falling-tree scars than otherwise, those through mistletoe knots accounted for the greatest amount of decay. Ordinary knots ranked third in number of infections and 2d in % of total decay. Infection through mistletoe burls and swollen limbs adjacent to the trunk accounted for 30.9% of the decay volume in board-feet. In general, western hemlocks were frequently infected at 60-85 yrs. of age, and decay became extensive at about 200 yrs. Conk rot and white trunk rot were most frequent on the Cascade areas, but Fomes root and white mottled rots were more common on the coast areas. Brown stringy rot was limited to trees of poor vigor at high elevations and on poor sites, and the injury from this cause was negligible in the commercial stands in western Oregon and Washington. There are 40 references,. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy Exp. Sta. Rec

TI: Precooling, freezing, and storage of dressed poultry
AU: COOK, W. H.
AB: Prompt precooling improves the efficiency of processing, reduces shrinkage, and inhibits growth of organisms causing spoilage. The drip obtained from minced muscle of birds precooled 24 hrs., decreased as freezing rate increased. The rate of freezing appears to have no effect on the number of bacteria present and little, if any, effect on the subsequent extent of surface desiccation or visceral taint. Taint development appears to depend primarily on the period during which the product is held above the freezing point, whether it occurs during precooling, freezing, or thawing. The principal factors causing deterioration of dressed poultry stored in the frozen state; namely, freezer burn, loss of bloom, and changes in fats, are discussed in relation to different storage conditions and methods for the prevention of these defects. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: H. Lindquist

TI: Wild animal damage to seed and seedlings on cut-over Douglas fir lands of Oregon and Washingto
AU: MOORE, A. W.
SO: TECH BULL U S DEPT AGRIC
AB: Slash disposal by fire after logging operations on the Douglas fir area of Oregon and Washington destroys desirable re-placement young growth, and recurring fires cause additional destruction. These fires do not remove many of the small animals that depend partly upon forest-tree seeds for food. White-footed mice (Peromyscus spp.) are the commonest and heaviest seed consumers. In live-trap studies, occurrence of Peromyscus over the winter period on 2 burned slash sites, each 200 ft. square, was 34 and 35 individuals, respectively. The animals were numbered and their travel recorded. Shrews are numerous in the moist coastal area and are also seed consumers. Squirrels are of little importance in forest regeneration. Douglas fir, hemlock, Sitka spruce, and western red cedar seeds are preferred in the order listed. Artificial reforestation by planting of nursery-grown stock, mainly 2-yr.-old Douglas fir, is retarded by cropping by rabbits common to the area. Mountain beavers, pocket gophers, bears, grouse, and porcupines also contribute to re-tardation of plantations. The animal instrumental may at times be determined by the type of injury. Port Orford cedar, a valuable and desirable species, suffers but little and is apparently avoided. Efforts to develop indices of damage have been un-successful. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: A. W. Moore

TI: Disease problems of Long Island duck raisers. World's Poultry Congr. and Expos
AU: HILBERT, E. F.
AB: The duck-raising industry on Long Island is of considerable importance. The high losses due to disease are mostly caused by fowl cholera and anati-pestifer infection. Symptoms of fowl cholera resemble those seen in chickens. The course of the disease is acute, losses up to 90% occurring in a week to 10 days. Those running a chronic course are thin and often lame, having swollen feet or joints. Severe hemorrhagic enteritis is usually present; the muscles are congested and dark; affected feet and joints contain reddish serous, whitish creamy, or yellowish cheesy exudate; affected air sacs are thickened and contain much cheesy exudate. Diagnosis rests primarily on bacteriological examination. Treatment except with extremely large doses of anti-hemorrhagic septi-cemia serum is of no value. Chemically killed autogenous bacterin is a means of control. Prompt disposal of dead birds by burning is important. Anatipestifer infection is a disease of young ducks caused by Pfiefferella anatipestifer. Death often occurs within 6-12 hrs. after symptoms are observed. Symptoms are those of depression which leads to complete prostration. Continual bobbing and jerking of the head are seen. A prominent lesion is an adherent fibrinous exudate covering the liver and heart. The lungs are congested, sometimes consolidated. Hemorrhagic enteritis is a prominent lesion. Diagnosis must be made by isolation of the causative organism. Treatment is of no avail. Control at the present time lies in strict sanitation an disposal of sick and dead birds by burning. Exptl. work indicates that a bacterin may be an aid to control. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: From auth. summ

TI: Insect and other pests of 1937
AU: CAMERON, A. E.
AB: The Antler Moth (Charaeas graminis) occurred in epidemic numbers and caused much damage. Full description of all the life stages is given. Attention is drawn to food plants, which are mostly of poor quality; to wandering habits which lead to their destruction in streams and by birds; to parasites, of which one, Ichneumon gradarius, was recorded and reared by the author; to environment, dry or wet hot conditions causing death of the eggs; and to control measures, of which deep trenching and periodical burning of hill pastures in late autumn are the best. A full acount of field slugs damaging potatoes (Agriolimax agrestis and Arion circumscriptus) is given. Special attention is given to the influence of environment, habit, and control. Poison baits include a paris green-bran mixture and meta fuel (paraformaldehyde). || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: C. E. Foister

TI: The Moa-hunters of New Zealan. Sportsmen of the stone age
AU: BUICK, T. LINDSAY
SO: The Moa-hunters of New Zealan. Sportsmen of the stone age
AB: Controversy over the date of extinction of the moas or giant struthionid birds of New Zealand has divided the ethnologists and palaeontologists of New Zealand into 2 schools, the one holding to the view of the great antiquity of this extinction and the other that this took place relatively recently. In its extreme form the earlier date is set at or about the time of the great migration to New Zealand or about 1350 AX). The evidence for this is the seeming absence of native records or legends about the birds, the apparent age of the steam-cooking ovens sunk in the earth, and in places the overlying shell middens of a later age. The 2d view is supported by somewhat questionable but internally consistent traditions, among older natives, as to the occurrence, habits, manner of hunting, and utilization as food of these giant birds. In places the shell and avian middens are intermingled. The latest date tentatively set for the view of recent extinction is about 300 years ago. The folklore indicates that the birds were stupid, harried to death by relays of hunters, or caught and roasted in forest fires. They were brought down from heights in mountain torrents in boats of rushes, cooked by steam over hot stones in sunken covered ovens. The long bones and in most cases the skull were broken open for the marrow and brain, respectively. The middens on old camp sites near the mouths of streams contain extensive deposits of dismembered skeletons, broken egg shells, mingled with gizzard stones (in some places), ashes, and wooden implements. Two types of stone implements, polished tools of a higher culture, and cruder flakes, the latter evidently used in carving the flesh of the moa and discarded, were also found. The author favors the view of the later date of extinction and of no great gap between an earlier and later culture of 2 successive peoples. The illustrations reveal the extensive deposits of skeletal remains. Lists of species identified at different camp sites which have been examined are given. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: C. A. Kojoid

TI: Artificial reforestation in the southern pine region
AU: WAKELEY, PHILIP C.
SO: U S DEPT AGRIC TECH BULL
AB: Artificial reforestation in the southern pine region of the U. S. A. is carried on chiefly with Pinus palustris, P. caribaea, P. taeda, and P. echinata. Many exotic conifers have been tried but none with conspicuous success. Except in areas of extreme erosion, planting is most frequently necessary because of failure of natural reproduction on soila formerly occupied by nearly pure stands of P. palustris. P. caribaea is the favorite sp. for reforestation in or near its natural range. The usual process of reforestation involves seed collection and extraction, and production and planting of l-yr.-old nursery stock; direct-seeding on the planting site has been unsatisfactory. The ave. numbers of seed per pound are: P. palustris 5200, P. caribaea 15,500, P. taeda 21,300 and P. echinata 69,200. Extraction of seed in modern, internal-fan kilns is just beginning to supplant extraction at air temp, indoors or in convection kilns. Dewinging of P. palustris seed is too difficult to be ordinarily feasible. Viability of seed, especially of P. palustris, in storage, is uncertain under most conditions, but well-dried seed of all spp. keeps well in sealed or tight containers at 38[degree] F. Germination tests in sand, with the seed covered not more than inch, have proved most generally satisfactory; a method employing compressed mats of acid peat has also worked well. Stratification in moist, acid peat at approximately 38[degree] F. for 30 days before testing or sowing greatly increases rapidity and percentage of germination, especially of spp. other than P. palustris. Nursery beds are usually sown in Feb. or March, and stock lifted in Nov., Dec, and Jan. Fertilizer has been little used. P. palustris seedlings are practically stemless, but have needles 12-18 inches long; planting stock of the other 3 spp. is usually 6-16 inches tall. Use of high-grade stock greatly improves survival and growth. Roots are pruned to 8 inches at the time of lifting. Planting is usually done on unprepared sites, or in shallow furrows, by 2 men using a 10-pound iron planting bar with a wedge-shaped blade. Height growth is rapid, except that of P. palustris, which is delayed for several yrs. after planting and then commences irregularly, so that the young stands have an extremely irregular crown canopy, in contrast to the even canopies of the other 3 pines. Principal nursery pests and diseases are birds (at sowing time), Phyllo-phaga larvae, cutworms, scale insects, and brown-spot needle-blight caused by Septoria acicola. Damping off is relatively rare. In plantations, P. palustris suffers most seriously from hogs and brown-spot; P. caribaea from fire and rabbits, and from windthrow after sleet storms; and P. taeda and P. echinata from fire, rabbits, and the Nantucket tip moth, Rhyacionia frustrana. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: P. C. Wakeley

TI: Decline of the noctuid genus Papaipema (Lepidoptera)
AU: BIRD, HENRY
AB: Several decades of field observations on the Papaipema group in the eastern U. S. A. are summarized and the attendant causes for decline weighed. Waste-land burnings constitute the chief menace, and complete extermination of the overwintering ova invariably follows such seasonal occurrences. Various vicissitudes which work against this group and factors constituting their normal balance are also discussed. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: H. Bird

TI: Einige Hauptztige der regionalen Verteilung der Brutvogelfauna in dem Seenge-biet von Kokemaenjoki
AU: CAJANDER, OLAVI
AB: Occupation of the region considered is closely correlated with the occurrence of productive soil. Relatively fruitful areas, which are thickly inhabited, and which as a rule lie at lower altitudes, alternate with swampy or barren areas the extent of which is greatest on the higher watersheds. The first are the "Kulturge-biete," the last "Hinterland" and "Einodengebiete," depending on whether they are sparsely inhabited or quite barren. Few natural forest stands are to be found. Fires and forest clearing have been widespread until recent years. The great stretches of moor land have been least disturbed. Characteristic birds of the Kulturgebiete include Pica pica, Sturnus vulgaris, Passer domesticus, Chloris chloris, Emberiza citronella, E. hortulana, and others. Those characteristic of the local wooded centers, "Hainzentren," are Coloeus monedula, Oriolus oriolns, Erythrina erythrina, Emberiza schoeniclus, Parus caeru-leus, and others. The ecological relations of the different spp. to the works of man and to the modified vegetation associated with civilization are various. Sturnus vulgaris, e.g., is much more widely distributed than would otherwise be the case as a result of providing nest boxes. Fires have caused the former fir woods to be replaced by deciduous timber, in consequence of which such birds as Parus major and Sylvia borin have extended their range. A number of spp. are quite intimately dependent on the parks, gardens, buildings, crops or grazing for which man is responsible. Others, as Sylvia atricapilla, are found only in those woods which approach most nearly to original conditions. Corvus corax, Cractes infaustus, Fringilla montijringilla, etc., occur in the "Einodengebiete." Some, as Pandion haliaetus, Colym-bus arcticus and C. stellatus, breed in the barrens, but feed on the lakes. The northward distr. of southern spp. of birds closely parallels the settlements of man. Most of the waterfowl, as Anas querquedula, Spatula clypeata, Nyroca ferina, and others, are restricted to the clay areas where as a rule are found waters rich in vegetation. Species vary greatly in the degree and character of their dependence on their surroundings. Climate may directly influence distribution of north-ranging birds of southerly affinities, or it may operate indirectly through its effect on soil factors. Most of the birds of southerly affinities belong to the youngest element in the fauna. Probably some of them have not as yet been able to occupy all accessible territory which is ecologically favorable. The average temp. of the summer months, especially July, is suggested as a possible factor limiting southward distr. of boreal spp. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: W. P. Taylor

TI: The bobwhite quail. Its habits, preservation and increase
AU: STODDARD, HERBERT L.; LEWIS S. THOMPSON
SO: The bobwhite quail. Its habits, preservation and increase
AB: This work, the result of a 5-yr. investigation conducted under the auspices of the U. S. Biological Survey, represents one of the most comprehensive and detailed accounts that has been published on the life history of an avian species. It was prepared for ornithologists, conservationists, sportsmen, and others interested in increasing the numbers of the bobwhite as a game bird. The investigation was carried on mainly in the territory between Thomasyille, Georgia, and Tallahassee, Florida. Studies of habitat requirements, food, enemies, parasites, and diseases receive particular emphasis. The species thrives where agriculture is somewhat primitive and cover about the borders of fields is not removed. Detailed accounts are given of courtship, nesting, care of eggs and young, social behavior, miscellaneous habits, vocabulary, rate of growth, development of plumage, color variations, and sex ratio. About 55 to 57% of adult birds appear to be [male][male].[long dash]A chapter on food and feeding habits (pp. 113-165), by C. O. HANDLEY and CLARENCE COTTAM, shows that about 86% of the. average monthly food is vegetable, and about 14% animal. Legumes, mast, a.nd fruit are the largest items in the vegetable food, and Orthoptera constitute more than half of the animal food.[long dash]Banding studies indicate that birds lost from their coveys rejoin them as opportunity occurs. The average range of a covey is not over 1/4 mi. Mortality, both before and after hatching, is high, owing to nest desertion, various natural enemies, and the elements. Loss from disease is apparently negligible. The greatest single cause of decrease is hunting by man. [long dash]A chapter on internal parasites and parasitic diseases (pp. 229-313) is contributed by ELOISE B. CRAM, MYRNA F. JONES, and ENA A. ALLEN. Four kinds of protozoan parasites were found. Coccidiosis (caused by Eimeria dispersa) is apparently much more of a menace to captive birds than to wild ones. Evidence of blackhead (caused by Histomonas meleagridis) was also found. Other parasites include trematodes (2 species), nematodes (16 species), and cestodes (5 species). A systematic account (by Cram, pp. 240-296) of the nematodes includes host records, location, description, life history, distribution, damage, treatment, and prevention. New host records are: Syngamus trachea*, Gongylonema ingluvicola, Capillaria annulata*, C. contorta, C. retusa, Tetrameres americana, Habronema pileata*, Cheilo-spirura spinosa, Ascaridea lineata*, Heterakis bonasae*, Subulura strongylina*, and Strongyloides avium, in Colinus virginianus Capillaria contorta in Phasianus colchicus from New York, in P. c. torquatus from Pennsylvania, in Dafila acuta from Louisiana, and in Lophortyx californica from California; Capillaria retusa in Perdix perdix from Pennsylvania, and in Meleagris gallopavo and Nurnida meleagris Seurocyrnea colini and Gongylonema ingluvicola in Meleagris gallopavo. Filariidae: APROCTELLA (p. 294), near Aprocta, type A. stoddardi Cram (p. 294), in abdominal cavity of Colinus virginianus (Georgia, Florida, and South Carolina) and Bonasa umbellus (New England) ; type in U. S. Nat. Mus. The previously unknown life histories of several nematodes were ascertained experimentally. Experimental production of cross-infections of nematodes from other birds to bobwhites or vice versa was accomplished in several instances. A systematic account of 5 cestodes (by Jones, pp. 297-310) includes host records, location, description, life history, distribution, pathology, control measures, and treatment. Allen (pp. 310-313) reports malaria in quail from Georgia and trichqmoniasis from Virginia.[long dash]Of external parasites, 5 Mallophaga, 4 Ixodoidea, 3 Acarina, and 1 flea are reported. A number of non-parasitic diseases are described. In a study of fluctuations in population nothing of a cyclic nature has been noted. The relations of agricultural activities and domestic animals to the bobwhite are discussed.[long dash]A chapter on quail preserve development and management (by H. L. Stoddard and C. 0. Handley, pp. 359-400) includes a discussion of the cultivation of plant foods for the species.[long dash]Other chapters treat of the use and abuse of fire on preserves, the control of natural enemies, and methods of capturing bobwhites.[long dash]There is a chapter on artificial propagation (pp. 451-489) by W.B.COLEMAN and H. L. Stoddard. [long dash]An appendix includes detailed tables of food items found in stomachs of bobwhites and a list of birds harboring nematode parasites of the bobwhite. The numerous plates (5 colored) illustrate many phases of the life history and environment of the species. There is a full index.

TI: Die Heteraciasis der Hiihner, hervorgerufen durch Heteracis papillosa, unter besonderer Beriicksichtigung der klinischen und patho-logisch-anatomischen Erscheinungen
AU: MOLLMAN, HANS
AB: This disease, due to H. papillosa, causes considerable loss among poultry. The clinical symptoms are: Loss of flesh in the initial stages, fatigue, ruffling and dulling of plumage, and loss of appetite; comb, wattles, and mucous membranes appear pale; gait becomes unsteady; in rare cases diarrhoea and shortness of breath occur. Death follows without paroxysms. The pathological anatomical changes are: Intestinal inflammation of a catarrhal or even haemorrhagic nature, gastritis, red hepatic atrophy, atrophy of the heart, cholecystitis, icterus, and inflammation of the. lungs. The treatment consists especially in prophylactic precautions; disinfection of the coops; planing smooth all wood surfaces; cleansing the feeding and drinking vessels; collecting and burning the feces; digging up the discharge-infested soil and refilling with fresh sand; and permanently drying out the entire premises. For medical treatment, anise oil gave good results if used before loss of flesh and internal changes had progressed too far. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author's summary (transl. by L. M. Dickerson)
